item.title: Measuring the Spot Variability of T Tauri Stars Using Near-IR Atomic Fe and Molecular OH Lines
item.description: Image credit: Figure 7 in Tang et al. 2024.: The empirical Teff vs. equivalent width ratio plot.

item.title: Binary Star Evolution in Different Environments: Filamentary, Fractal, Halo and Tidal-tail Clusters
item.description: Image credit: Figure 5 in Pang et al. 2023.: Box plot showing radial binary fraction as a function of cluster-centric distance as half-mass radius (rh). For each panel shows four types of clusters: (a) filamentary , (b) fractal, (c) halo , and (d) tidal-tail.

item.title: Star-Crossed Lovers DI Tau A and B: Orbit Characterization and Physical Properties Determination
item.description: Image credit: Figure 2 in Tang et al. 2023.: Best model fit for DITau AB

item.title: Dynamical Origin for the Collinder 132-Gulliver 21 Stream: A Mixture of three Co-Moving Populations with an Age Difference of 250 Myr
item.description: Image credit: Figure 3 in Pang et al. 2022.: 3D morphology of the Collinder 132-Gulliver 21 stream. The oldest population surrounded by young populations can be seen in panel (b) with age of each group labeled.

item.title: 3D Morphology of Open Clusters in the Solar Neighborhood with Gaia EDR3 II: Hierarchical Star Formation Revealed by Spatial and Kinematic Substructures
item.description: Image credit: Figure 3 in Pang et al. 2022.: 3D morphology of 85 open clusters in the solar neighborhood with the color of the cluster scaled with the logarithm of age. An interactive version of this figure is available at http://3doc-morphology.lowell.edu

item.title: Disruption of Hierarchical Clustering in the Vela OB2 Complex and the Cluster Pair Collinder 135 and UBC 7 with Gaia EDR3: Evidence of Supernova Quenching
item.description: Image credit: Figure 8 in Pang et al. 2021.: IRAS-IRIS infrared image of the 60 $\mu m$ band. The members of Huluwa 1–5, and the cluster pair Collinder135 and UBC7 are displayed as colored dots.

item.title: Impacts of Water Latent Heat on the Thermal Structure of Ultra-Cool Objects: Brown Dwarfs and Free-Floating Planets
item.description: Image credit: Figure 1 in Tang et al. 2021.: Thermal structure profiles from converged solutions of the radiative-convective model at logg = 4.0 for YB ([M/H] of 0.0, here) and YP ([M/H] of 0.7 and 1.5) cases.

item.title: 3D Morphology of Open Clusters in the Solar Neighborhood with Gaia EDR3: its Relation to Cluster Dynamics
item.description: Image credit: Figure 8 in Pang et al. 2021.: Elipsoid fitting for the 3D spatial positions for the cluster members within tidal radius of NGC 2516, after distance correction through a Bayesian approach (see Section 4.1).

item.title: Different Fates of Young Star Clusters After Gas Expulsion
item.description: Image credit: Figure 5 in Pang et al. 2020.: Number density, mass density, and mean mass distributions along a clustercentric distance r for NGC 2232 (blue curves) and LP 2439 (red curves).

item.title: Discovery of Tidal Tails in Disrupting Open Clusters: Coma Berenices and a Neighbor Stellar Group
item.description: Image credit: Tang et al. 2019.: 3D spatial, proper motion, and radial velocity plot for Coma Ber & Group-X.

item.title: Characterization of Stellar and Substellar Members in the Coma Berenices Star Cluster
item.description:
Image credit: Tang et al. 2018. Figure 17: The present day mass function (MF) of the ~800 Myr old Coma Ber star cluster.

Key Takeaways

  • The Mass Function (MF) of Coma Berenices peaks at 0.3 $M_\odot$:
    • The slope of the MF, $\alpha$, is approximately 0.49 $\pm$ 0.03 for the mass range 0.3 to 2.3 $M_{\odot}$.
  • The value of $\alpha$ for Coma Berenices is lower than that of the Salpeter initial mass function, which is 2.35 for masses between 1–10 $M_{\odot}$ in the solar neighborhood.
  • The value of $\alpha$ for Coma Berenices is also lower than the present-day MF for field M dwarfs, which is approximately 1.3 for masses between 0.1–0.7 $M_{\odot}$ (Reid et al. 2002).
